clinical_study.brief_title: Transverse Supraumbilical Versus Pfannenstiel Incision for Cesarean Section in Morbidly Obese Women
clinical_study.official_title: Transverse Supraumbilical Versus Pfannenstiel Incision For Cesarean Section in Morbid Obese Patients" A Single Blinded Randomized Controlled Trial"

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of transverse supraumbilical incision over Pfannenstiel incision in performing cesarean section for morbid obese pregnant women.

detailed_description.textblock: Research Question In Morbidly obese women undergoing cesarean section, is transverse supraumbilical incision superior to Pfannenstiel incision? Research Hypothesis Transverse supraumbilical incision is superior to Pfannenstiel incision in morbidly obese women undergoing cesarean section.

primary_outcome.description: occurance of redness, hotness, pus discharge and exudation

secondary_outcome.description: from skin incision to closure of the skin
volume of blood during the operation

arm_group.description: transverse Supraumbilical Incision, in which the skin incision is a straight transverse skin incision slightly higher than the Pfannenstiel (5- 6) cm. from the upper border of the symphysis pubis The high transverse incision facilitated access to the fascia of the rectus abdominalis. Above the panniculus, the fatty tissues are not particularly thick. A transverse opening of the aponeurosis and of the parietal peritoneum was done. Then the approach to the lower uterine segment was easy. A Ricard retractor was put in place.

Pfannenstiel Incision, in which the skin incision is a transverse upward concavity, typically initiated two finger-breadths above the symphysis pubis and extended in the direction of the anterior superior iliac spine below and medial to it about (2 - 3 ) cm.

- BMI more than 40 kg/m2
- women scheduled for CS
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients receiving steroids or anticoagulation
